properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions continue. Although there may be intermittent improvement today and tonight, poor visibility will persist until Friday morning with wind gusts near 80 km/h. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T02:38:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-19T10:39:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0794121981.2020
Area: Paulatuk
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Spring storm expected Friday with snow, rain, winds and risk of freezing rain. Precipitation will begin as snow on Friday morning before changing over to rain in the evening. A short period of freezing rain is also possible during the transition. Significant amounts of snow and rain are likely. Strong winds will also accompany this storm. ### Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T07:03:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-19T15:04:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3007341282.2020
Area: Chevery, Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain this evening followed by snow Friday. Rain, heavy at times, will begin this evening. Rainfall amounts in the 15 to 25 mm range are possible by the time the rain changes to snow on Friday. Snowfall amounts are not expected to be more than a few centimetres at this point. If visibility is reduced while driving, turn on your lights and maintain a safe following distance. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T01:53:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-19T09:54:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3277150268.2020
Area: Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island, Greater Sudbury and vicinity, West Nipissing - French River, North Bay - Powassan - Mattawa, Blind River - Thessalon, Espanola - Killarney, Manitoulin Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain tonight changing to snow Friday. Rain, heavy at times, will begin this evening with amounts in the 15 to 25 mm range possible. The rain may be preceded by flurries or showers this afternoon. Overnight into Friday morning, the passage of a strong cold front will cause temperatures to rapidly fall, transitioning rain to snow. The snow will taper off by Friday evening, with total snowfall amounts up to 10 cm expected by the time the snow comes to an end. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T07:17:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-19T15:18:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1242786538.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Possible freezing rain then rain on Friday. A low will track into Western Quebec Thursday night. Precipitation may start as freezing rain before changing to rain more or less rapidly. A general 15 to 25 millimetres of rain is expected through Friday evening. Untreated surfaces could become icy and slippery. Runoff could be important locally. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Summary:

Total snowfall amounts up to 15 cm are expected by the time the snow tapers off Friday afternoon. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain and Scattered Thunderstorms This Evening and Tonight. Scattered Thunderstorms and Potential High Wind Gusts Friday. An approaching warm front will cause an area of showers and thunderstorms to move through the regions this evening and tonight. Some of the storms will contain heavy downpours with local rainfall amounts of 15 to 25 mm in an hour possible. There will be the potential for high wind gusts Friday in the morning or early afternoon as a cold front approaches, preceded by a band of scattered showers and thunderstorms. Winds gusts of 90 km/h will be possible in this band. Should these winds develop, power outages would likely occur in some areas. Environment Canada will continue to monitor this situation closely and may issue watches or warnings as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T06:32:29-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme cold wind chill values near minus 45 are expected to moderate later today as temperatures rise. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR BURNS LAKE AND SMITHERS The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has continued a Road Dust Advisory for Burns Lake and Smithers because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation or dust suppression. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-03-20T03:56:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-03-19T11:57:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1304771951.2020
Area: Bulkley Valley, Lakes District
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and blowing snow expected this evening into Friday. Snow will begin this morning and become heavy by this evening. Snow, heavy at times, will continue tonight before tapering off Friday morning. Total snowfall amounts near 25 cm are expected by the time the snow comes to an end. In addition, northerly wind gusts of 50 to 60 km/h are expected tonight into Friday, resulting in blowing snow, particularly over exposed areas. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard or near blizzard conditions continuing for Clyde River most of the day. An intense low pressure system over southern Davis Strait is causing strong northwest winds of 50 gusting 70 km/h at Clyde River. Similar conditions will persist through most of the day today giving poor visibilities in blowing snow until either late afternoon or early evening after which time winds should start to slowly diminish. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T05:24:18-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Snow, heavy at times, tonight. Snow will begin today over regions near Fire River, Peterbell, and Elsas. Snow will become heavy at times this evening before tapering off on Friday. Total snowfall amounts up to 20 cm are expected by the time the snow comes to an end. Precipitation will be mixed with rain in areas closer to Chapleau later today and change to snow this evening. Snowfall amounts up to 15 cm are possible by Friday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain and wind expected to end the week. Total rainfall: generally 30 to 50 mm with locally higher amounts possible along the south coast. Maximum wind gusts: generally 80 km/h except locally 120 km/h or higher in areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Locations: southern and western Newfoundland. Time span: Friday morning through Saturday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Friday morning, and then quickly transition through freezing precipitation before changing to rain at times heavy late Friday. Snowfall amounts are not expected to be significant at this time. Strong winds will also develop Friday morning, with the highest gusts occurring over areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Conditions will improve Saturday morning. Milder temperatures will accompany the rainfall and will cause significant snowmelt and runoff leading to potential flooding. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-20T05:33:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-19T13:34:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2480458136.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds expected beginning Friday. Total snowfall: 15 cm or more. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 100 km/h or higher along the Mid Labrador Coast. Locations: Labrador. Time span: Friday through Saturday night. Remarks: Snow is expected to spread across Labrador on Friday. The snow may change to rain or freezing rain over southeastern parts of Labrador Friday night before changing back to snow on Saturday. On Saturday, strong northwesterly winds are expected to combine with snow along the Labrador Coast to bring poor visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions will improve by Sunday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-20T05:42:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-19T13:43:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3521094306.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant Rain, Thunderstorms, and Potential Strong Wind Gusts on the way. An approaching warm front will cause an area of showers and thunderstorms to move through the regions this evening. Some of the storms will contain heavy downpours with local rainfall amounts of 25 mm in an hour possible. A few showers or thunderstorms are also expected overnight in some areas. There is the risk that isolated thunderstorms overnight could contain wind gusts to 90 km/h. A greater threat for high wind gusts is expected Friday morning into early afternoon as a cold front approaches, preceded by a band of scattered showers and thunderstorms. There will be potential for wind gusts of 90 km/h as the band moves through. Should these winds develop, power outages would likely occur in some areas. Environment Canada will continue to monitor this situation closely and may issue watches or warnings as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
